headline: Pennsylvania Democrats unable to endorse candidate for U.S. Senate
author: Sanika Bhargaw
sentences:
Davis said, “We’re ready to go out and build a coalition that’s going to win in November.”
With a crowded Republican field, the state GOP is unlikely to endorse a candidate for governor or Senate, according to Nicholas.
SWATARA TOWNSHIP, Pa. (WHTM) — The Pennsylvania Democratic Committee met Saturday to endorse candidates for three statewide races: governor, lieutenant governor and U.S. Senate.
“You’re going to have a very competitive Senate race, Senate primary on both sides, and I think that Senate race is going to overshadow the governor’s race,” Nicholas said.
The state Democratic committee endorsed Attorney General Josh Shapiro for governor and State Rep. Austin Davis for lieutenant governor, both in the first round of voting.
“I think we showed that we have the strongest argument not just to win the primary, but to win in November, which is what everybody cares about,” he said.
Republican political consultant Christopher Nicholas said the second place finish was a surprise for the number two Democrat in the state.
Governor John Fetterman finished second, with less than a quarter of the vote, and State Rep. Malcolm Kenyatta finished third.
“We’re going to take this message, meet people where they are, visit with them, listen to them,” Shapiro said.

There are at least 14 Republicans running for governor, and eight candidates for Senate.
After two rounds of voting, state Democrats offered no endorsement for U.S. Senate.
